metadata.title: Supported monocationic copper(II) complexes obtained by coordination with dialkylphosphonate groups on styrene–divinylbenzene copolymer as catalysts for oxidation of organic compounds

S (%) Catalyst PPO(OCH3)2 PPO(OC2H5)2 PPO(O i C3H7)2 PPO(O n C4H9)2 Cu(at) Cu(hf) Cu(at) Cu(hf) Cu(at) Cu(hf) Cu(at) Cu(hf) S guaiacol 98 69 90 90 100 79 95 75 S catechol 40 95 83 87 85 89 81 91 S benzaldehide 85 100 80 78 81 98 65 85 Supported monocationic copper(II) complexes obtained by coordination with dialkylphosphonate groups on styrene–divinylbenzene copolymer as catalysts for oxidation of organic compounds Viorica Parvulescu a ⁎ Violeta Niculescu a b Ramona Ene a ⁎ Adriana Popa c Mihaela Mureseanu d Cristian D. Ene e Marius Andruh e a “Ilie Murgulescu” Institute of Physical Chemistry, Romanian Academy, Splaiul Independentei 202, 060021 Bucharest, Romania b National Research and Development Institute for Cryogenics and Isotopes Technologies – ICIT, 4th Uzinei Street, 240050 Ramnicu Valcea, Romania c Institute of Chemistry Timisoara of Romanian Academy, Romanian Academy, 24 Mihai Viteazul Blv., Timisoara, Romania d University of Craiova, Faculty of Chemistry, Calea Bucuresti 107I, Craiova, Romania e University of Bucharest, Faculty of Chemistry, Department of Inorganic Chemistry, 23 Dumbrava Rosie Street, Bucharest, Romania ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Highlights ► Mononuclear Cu(II) complexes anchored on functionalized polymer supports. ► Supports are phosphonate-functionalized styrene–divinylbenzene copolymer. ► Phosphonate groups of supports influence Cu(II) complexes properties. ► Materials are catalytically active in liquid phase oxidation of organic compounds. ► Equilibrium of steric and inductive effect influences catalytic properties. New catalysts were synthesized by immobilization of neutral and monocationic copper complexes Cu(hfac)2 (hfac− =hexafluoroacetylacetonato ligand) and [Cu(acac)(tmen)]NO3 (acac− =acetylacetonato ligand, tmen=N,N,N′,N′-tetramethyl-ethylendiamine) on styrene–divinylbenzene copolymer functionalized with four different dialkyl phosphonate moieties typified by PPO(OR)2 (with R= CH3, C2H5, i C3H7, and n C4H9). The formation of P(O)(OR)2 phosphonates groups has been confirmed by the FT-IR spectra. Thermogravimetric analysis results reveal that the thermal stability of polymer support depend on the functional group attached. The complexes were anchored by coordination interaction between the copper(II) ion and the phosphonate oxygen atom on each of the four functionalized supports and the strength of the PO⋯Cu n+ coordination interaction was influenced by the nature of the R group. The effect of functionalized supports on the structure and catalytic activity of Cu(hfac)2 and [Cu(acac)(tmen)]+ mononuclear species was determined in oxidation of several organic compounds (anisole, cyclohexene, toluene, styrene, phenol) with hydrogen peroxide. The catalytic activity results show that the activity and selectivity of Cu(II) complexes depends on the equilibrium between steric factor and inductive electron-releasing effect. The best selectivity was obtained in oxidation of anisole, phenol and styrene for all the catalysts. The main products were for 2-methoxyphenol, catechol and benzaldehyde, respectively. Keywords Supported catalysts Polymer-supported Cu(II) complexes Oxidation catalyst Hydrogen peroxide 1 Introduction Investigation on metal–organic complexes represents one of the most active areas of material science and chemical research. Major advances have been made in the synthesis of these materials due to their interesting properties and potential in various applications as host–guest chemistry, ion exchange and catalysis [1–4]. The transitional metal complexes have been supported on various materials, but the microenvironment created by polymeric supports provided a better control on the efficiency of the catalysts in organic compounds reactions compared to inorganic oxides. Heterogenization of catalysts has been the subject of many publications in this topic [5–7] and has attracted a high interest due to its advantages, especially the possibility of combining the advantages of homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts that sometimes might minimize the drawbacks of both [8]. Special interest has been addressed to catalytic applications of polystyrene-supported ligands and metal complexes [9–11,7]. The immobilization of transition metals on polystyrene supports, which is still one of the most popular polymeric materials used in synthesis due to its low cost, ready availability, mechanical robustness, chemical inertness, and facile functionalization [12], offers a number of advantages toward the traditional solution-phase chemistry. Generally, the organic groups of the functionalized polymer are the coordination sites that bind metal ions. Suitable bonds between the support and the metallic ions are crucial for the effective performance of the catalyst [13]. The polymer-anchored reagents can react, by covalent bonds, with metal ion of the complex, with ligands or precursors of the metals. The recovery of these catalysts is effective and leaching is low comparatively with physically linked supported catalysts. The aim of this work is the evaluation of a new group of neutral and monocationic metal complexes supported on styrene–divinylbenzene copolymer functionalized with phosphonate groups, from their synthesis to their application in the catalytic oxidation of organic compounds (such as anisole, cyclohexene, toluene, styrene and phenol) with hydrogen peroxide. In this study, polymeric chelating resins containing phosphonate functional groups [14–18] were synthesized by chemical modification of the polymer support. Dialkylphosphonate moiety can bind metal ions through the oxygen donor atom of the PO group. However, an organic phosphonate acts rather as a weak ligand and highly Lewis acidic metal centers are needed for complex formation [19,20]. Accordingly, we have chosen unsaturated mononuclear copper(II) complexes with hexafluoroacetylacetonato anion that have proved to possess an enhanced binding affinity for molecules with a reduced donor ability such as radical-substituted ligands, neutral organic or organometallic spacers [21–26]. An alternative strategy involves the use of mixed-ligand copper(II) complexes of [Cu(AA)(BB)]+ type (where AA stands for acetylacetonate or salicylaldehydate, and BB for a chelating bidentate diamine, e.g. 1,10-phenanthroline or 2,2′-bipyridine), whose apical position at the copper(II) ion has shown a remarkable availability for the metal ion interaction with various ligands [27,28]. The equilibrium between steric factor and inductive electron-releasing effect was correlated with the oxidative catalytic activity of the new heterogeneous catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of the polymeric supports The synthesis of the phosphonates grafted on a macroporous styrene–7% divinylbenzene copolymer support was performed by the method previously described [16,18]. The commercial chloromethylated styrene–divinylbenzene copolymer (S–7%DVB, 13.84mmol CH2Cl), macroporous type, was used as starting material. All the other reagents were used without any purification. In a 100mL round bottom flask fitted with stirrer, reflux condenser and thermometer, 3g of PS and 50mL N,N-dimethylformamide were added. The mixture was then maintained under stirring for 2h at room temperature for copolymer beads swelling. Then, dialkylphosphite and sodium carbonate were added, in order to achieve a molar ratio chloromethyl groups:diphosphite:sodium carbonate=1:1.2:1 and 0.05% tetramethylammonium iodide catalyst, respectively. The mixture was kept under stirring for 24h at 100°C. The polymer beads separated by filtration were washed with 0.1N HCl (3×20mL), ethanol (3×20mL), 1,2-dichloromethane (3×20mL) and ethyl ether (3×20mL), and dried under 2kPa vacuum at 50°C for 24h. 2.2 Synthesis and immobilization of the complexes Copper bis(hexafluoroacetylacetonate) complex (Cu(hfac)2) was purchased from commercial sources and was used as received. The [Cu(acac)(tmen)]NO3 complex (where acac− =acetylacetonato anion, and tmen=N,N,N′,N′-tetramethyl-ethylendiamine) was synthesized through a procedure previously reported for similar derivatives [29–32] as follows: an ethanolic solution (15mL) of acetylacetone (400.4mg, 4mmol) deprotonated with triethylamine (404mg, 4mmol) was mixed with 464.8mg of N,N,N′,N′-tetramethyl-ethylenediamine (4mmol) dissolved in 15mL ethanol. The resulted solution was rapidly added to 25–30mL water/ethanol (1:1, v/v) solution of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (966.4mg, 4mmol). The dark-blue crystals obtained on slow evaporation of the solvents were separated by filtration, washed with small amounts of ethanol and water, and dried in air (yield: 75%). Selected IR data (KBr, cm−1): 3008(w), 2974(w), 2922(w), 2895(w), 1589(m), 1553(m), 1516(m), 1385(vs), 1021(m), 953(m), 809(m). The immobilization of Cu(hfac)2 and [Cu(acac)(tmen)]+ complex entities (where hfac− =hexafluoroacetylacetonate) on phosphonate-containing copolymer supports was carried out using the following general synthetic route: 350mg of the chosen phosphonate-modified styrene–divinylbenzene copolymer was suspended into the solution of the appropriate complex (150mg) in 15–20mL acetonitrile and refluxed for 6–7h. The resulted mixture was filtered while warm, and the solid product was washed at room temperature with acetonitrile to colorless filtrate and dried in air. In order to remove as much as possible the physically adsorbed complex species, a Soxhlet extraction in acetonitrile was performed for 6–8h (2–3 cycles per hour). The solid products were finally dried in a CaCl2 desiccator. 2.3 Characterization of the materials Styrene–divinylbenzene copolymer functionalized with phosphonate groups were characterized by Fourier transformed infrared spectroscopy with a Jasco FTIR spectrophotometer and SEM microscopy (Zeiss EVO LZ 10 EP, FEI Quanta 3D FEG). The thermal analysis of samples was performed with TG 209 (Netzsch) in nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 5°C/min in the range 20–600°C. The quantitative analysis of metal loadings of the catalyst was carried out by atomic adsorption spectroscopy on Spectra AA 110 Varian spectrometer equipped with Varian multi-element hollow cathode lamps and air-acetylene burner. The phosphorus content was determined according to modified Schoninger method [16,33]. The IR spectra of the metal complex-based materials (KBr pellets) were collected on a Bruker Tensor 37 spectrophotometer in the 4000–400cm−1 range, and the UV–Vis–NIR diffuse reflectance spectra were recorded on a JASCO V-570 spectrophotometer in the 190–1200nm region, using MgO as a standard. The obtained catalysts were tested in oxidation of the organic compounds (anisole, cyclohexene, toluene, styrene, phenol). The oxidation reactions were carried out in glass mini reactors (5mL) at 50°C for 8h, using 0.05g catalysts and a 1/20/3 molar ratio substrate/solvent (acetonitrile)/H2O2. The analysis of oxidation products was performed using a DANI GC 1000 gas chromatograph connected to a FID detector. The active compound leaching during the reaction was verified by resubmission of filtrates to reaction conditions. Product identification was achieved by comparison with GC peaks of the authentic compounds and GC–MS analysis that was performed on a Thermo Scientific chromatograph equipped with MS DSQ II Thermo and capillary column TR-5MS (30m×0.25 ID×0.25μm film thickness). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Preparation and characterization of the functionalized polymers and supported Cu(II) complexes New polymeric supports functionalized with four different dialkyl phosphonate moieties have been synthesized. The structure of the resins proposed in Fig. 1 is supported by FTIR spectra. Some general remarks concerning the analysis of the FTIR spectra (see Fig. 2 ) are as follows: (i) the formation of P(O)(OR)2 phosphonates groups on the styrene–7% divinylbenzene copolymer was confirmed by the increase in the intensity of the absorption band at around 1220cm−1 associated with the vibration of the PO bond, (ii) the characteristic POH band appears at around 1000cm−1 and (iii) a medium intensity band at 1600cm−1 is assigned to the P(O)OH group. The main characteristics of the copolymer functionalized with phosphonates groups are presented in Table 1 . The calculated functionalization degrees found by the analysis above can be explained by the hypothesis that, in spite of extensive swelling of the starting copolymer, some reactive chloromethyl groups are embedded into the micropores of the copolymer “pearls” and could not be accessed by the bulky functionalization agent [14]. The degrees of functionalization with phosphonates groups are relatively high, ensuring a sufficient concentration of active centers per unit mass of the copolymer and being well-suited for application as polymer supported catalysts. The best functionalization was obtained for the PSPO(OCH3)2 hybrid support (2.1mmol/g). The thermogravimetric analyses (TG) of the of polymeric supports and immobilized Cu(II) complexes were measured in order to investigate the thermal stability. TG analysis indicated changes in thermal stability of the polymers functionalized with pendant phosphonate groups in comparison with the support of macromolecular chloromethylated styrene–divinylbenzene (Table 2 ). The thermal stability is affected by the nature of the R radicals of the phosphonate groups, the initial support having a better thermal stability. It was showed that degradation of the polymer support functionalized with different dialkyl phosphonate moieties was gradual until 300°C for all the supports and catalysts except the samples with OC2H5 group. From the decomposition profile, it appears a lower weight loss between 20 and 400°C (Fig. 3 ). This is a result of the polymer and Cu(II) complexes functions and ligands decomposition. The sharp drop mass evidence at around 400°C for all the samples is a result of poly(styrene–divinyl benzene) co-polymer degradation. The effect of alkyl chains of phosphonate alcohol radicals is evidenced in Fig. 3 and also the insignificant Cu(II) complex on thermal stability. SEM images of the spherical particles of styrene–7% divinylbenzene copolymer support functionalized with PO(OC2H5)2 and their morphology are presented in Fig. 4 . The macropores are visible among the agglomerations of micro-particles, characterized by a dense structure. The as-synthesized polymeric supports functionalized with dialkyl phosphonate moieties were used thereafter for the immobilization of Cu(hfac)2 and [Cu(acac)(tmen)]+ complex entities. A very good and homogeneous dispersion of Cu(II) complex particles on the copolymer support was evidenced by SEM microscopy (Fig. 5 ). We believe that this sustain the immobilization of the complexes by coordination interaction between the copper(II) ion and the phosphonate oxygen atom of the functionalized supports. The SEM images (Fig. 5) show the change of Cu(II) complexes morphology after immobilization. The new Cu(II) complexes on the polymer surface are spherical formations with diameters around 500nm. The as-synthesized polymeric supports functionalized with dialkyl phosphonate moieties were used thereafter for the immobilization of Cu(hfac)2 and [Cu(acac)(tmen)]+ complex entities. As a common feature of the infrared absorption spectra for the products based on isolated copper complex – copolymer, the strong band due to the stretching vibration of the PO bond shifts to lower frequencies (Δν >50cm−1), indicating the involvement of this group in the coordination of the metal ion. Nevertheless, the PO band characteristic to the initial supports is also present at a relatively lower intensity pointing to the existence of a fraction of free phosphonate groups. On the other hand, the band modifications in the region 1660–1600cm−1 arise from CO stretching vibration of acetylacetonato-type ligand. In addition, FTIR spectra of materials containing [Cu(acac)(tmen)]NO3 present a sharp band of medium-to-strong intensity at around 1383cm−1 that is associated with the nitrate anion. The diffuse reflectance spectra of the compounds resulted in the reaction of copper(II) complexes with the functionalized copolymers show a large asymmetric band in the region 600–1200nm due to d–d transitions. In the case of dimethyl and diisopropyl phosphonate derivatives, the above-mentioned band exhibits a significantly reduced intensity compared to those occurring in the UV region, being attributed to the transitions characteristic to the polymeric organic substrate. As for diethyl and di-n-buthyl phosphonate-based products, the maxima of the two categories of bands are approximately equal in magnitude (Figs. 6 and 7 ). These differences might be related to the ligand-field symmetry and strength that affect the metal ion–donor atom bond stability and ultimately influence the abundance of the complex entities immobilized on polymeric supports. In this regard, the PO⋯Cu2+ coordination interaction appears to define a structural feature whose relevance depends on the equilibrium established between the following factors: (i) the steric hindrance generated by the alkyl group of the phosphonate, which diminishes from isopropyl and n-butyl to ethyl and methyl and (ii) the inductive electron-releasing effect of R group that increases in the sequence CH3 < C2H5 < n C4H9 < i C3H7. On the basis of this information and knowing that the donor atoms of the chelating ligands occupy the basal plane of the copper(II) coordination sphere [34,35] it is legitimate to consider a distorted octahedral geometry of the metal center, where the axial positions belong to phosphonate oxygen atom and to a solvent molecule or nitrate anion, respectively (Fig. 6). However, the coexistence of five-coordinated complex species, namely Cu(hfac)2 moieties with the PO group occupying the apical site, is not excluded (see Fig. 8 ). 3.2 Catalytic evaluation The obtained supported metal complexes are active and selective in oxidation of organic compounds (anisole, cyclohexene, toluene, styrene, phenol) with hydrogen peroxide. The differences between the conversions of the organic substrates were related to the strength of the PO⋯Cu2+ coordination interaction depending mainly on the nature of the R group and on the ligands of the Cu(II) complexes. Thus, [Cu(acac)(tmen)]NO3 complex supported on styrene–divinylbenzene copolymer functionalized with PO(O n C4H9)2 group had lower activity in all the oxidation reactions (Fig. 9 ). Furthermore, for all the phosphonate groups, the toluene oxidation activities are the lowest. The highest conversions were obtained in oxidation of cyclohexene and anisole, respectively, in phenol oxidation on the copolymer supports functionalized with PO(OC2H5) and PO(OCH3)2. These results confirm the significant influence of the steric effect. An increased activity was obtained in oxidation of cyclohexene and anisole on [Cu(acac)(tmen)]NO3 complex supported on styrene–divinylbenzene copolymer functionalized with PO(O i C3H7). This sustains the involvement of the equilibrium between steric and electronic effects on the oxidative catalytic activity. The same catalytic tests on Cu(hfac)2 complex supported on styrene–divinylbenzene copolymer functionalized with phosphonate groups revealed, comparatively with the first complex, a lower conversion of phenol and a higher one for toluene in their oxidation reactions with hydrogen peroxide (Fig. 10 ). A very low activity was obtained in oxidation of phenol, for all catalysts based on Cu(hfac)2 and in oxidation of styrene on copolymer functionalized with PO(O n C4H9)2. The comparative analysis of the catalytic results (Fig. 9) with those of the electronic spectra (Fig. 6) evidences a positively effect of strong PO⋯Cu2+ interaction and negatively effect of steric effect of PO(O n C4H9)2 group. Even if for the catalysts based on Cu(hfac)2 complex the effect of PO⋯Cu2+ interaction is lower, the enhancement of the catalytic performances (see comparatively Figs. 9 and 10) can be attributed to the favorable influence of hfac− ligand on catalytic activity. Comparatively catalytic tests of Cu(II) complexes and functionalized polymers showed an insignificantly activity of l-Cu than supports. In this case we consider that catalytic activity is a result of phosphonate groups activity and their effect on copper ions. The analysis of the reaction products shows, for all these processes, the activation of CH bond with H2O2 like hydroxyl radicals. The formation of OH radicals detected by ESR [36] in reaction conditions can be explained by mechanism of peroxide decomposition in the presence of Cu(II) complexes [37]. Therefore, the catalytic processes are the result of competition between organic compounds adsorption and l-Cu2+ ⇔ l-Cu+ processes. The organic properties of the support increase adsorption properties and the Cu(II) complex promotes decomposition of hydrogen peroxide to OH radicals. Thus, the products of cyclohexene oxidation were 2-cyclohexene-1-ol, 2-cyclohexene-1-one and cyclohexane-1,2-diol and of toluene oxidation were o- and p-cresol, benzaldehyde and benzoic acid. For oxidation of anisole the resulting products are 2- or 4-methoxyphenol and for oxidation of phenol, the products are catechol and o- or p-benzoquinone. In the oxidation of the above mentioned compounds, the higher selectivity was for 2- methoxyphenol (guaiacol) and catechol, respectively. The best selectivity toward catechol was obtained for Cu(hfac)2 complex (Table 3 ). A very low selectivity to catechol was obtained for the [Cu(acac)(tmen)]NO3 complex supported on styrene–divinylbenzene copolymer functionalized with PPO(O n C4H9)2 groups. For this catalyst, the steric effect of n-butyl radical on selectivity and conversion was similar (Fig. 7, Table 3). The decrease of the phenol conversion and selectivity to catechol were considered as a result of the steric and higher hydrophobic effects of (O n C4H9)2 groups. These alcoxide groups have the limitative effect on the phenol adsorption. Thus, in the first 5h of the reaction the conversion of phenol was very low in opposition with the others compounds. The selectivity toward guaiacol in the anisole oxidation reaction was high for all the tested catalysts (Table 3). For all the oxidation reaction of the aromatic compounds, except styrene, the mechanism is typical for hydroxylation processes [38]. Only in case of the styrene oxidation, the CC bond was activated and the highest activity was obtained for [Cu(acac)(tmen)]NO3 complex immobilized on the copolymer functionalized with PO(O i C3H7). In this reaction the electronic effect was more important for the complex catalytic activity. The analysis of the products resulted in oxidation of styrene evidence the splitting of CC bond of the vinyl radical and formation of benzaldehyde and benzoic acid as oxidation products. A very high selectivity toward benzaldehyde was evidenced for all the tested catalysts (Table 3). A low percent of the degradation products was obtained in oxidation of styrene and phenol, respectively. The catalytic properties of PSPO(OR)2CuL catalysts were confirmed by recycling the complex in three consecutive experiments using anisole as model substrate. The catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture after each experiment by filtration, washed with solvent and dried carefully before using it in the subsequent run. The results are shown a little reduction of anisole conversion after first-reaction cycle. In the second and third-reaction cycle any variation of conversion was evidenced. A small quantity of the leached copper species was detected after first-cycle reaction. 4 Conclusions Cu(hfac)2 and [Cu(acac)(tmen)]+ mononuclear species were anchored on polymer-supported dialkyl phosphonates, typified by PPO(OR)2 (with R= CH3, C2H5, i C3H7, and n C4H9). The FTIR spectra of the complex-containing materials indicated the involvement of the oxygen atom belonging to the phosphoryl group in the coordination of the metal center. The differences observed in the diffuse reflectance spectra of the catalysts containing the same copper(II) complex were related to the strength of the PO⋯Cu n+ coordination interaction that is ultimately influenced by the nature of the R group. The significantly influences of the metal interactions with the functionalized supports, the nature of the ligands in these new catalysts based on copper complexes and the alcohol radical of the phosphonate groups grafted onto the polymeric support were evidenced on catalytic activity and selectivity. Such behavior was considered as a result of the equilibrium between a steric factor and an inductive electron-releasing effect. The analysis of the reactions products of all the reactions, except styrene, reveals the activation of CH bond. coredata.dc:description: New catalysts were synthesized by immobilization of neutral and monocationic copper complexes Cu(hfac)2 (hfac− =hexafluoroacetylacetonato ligand) and [Cu(acac)(tmen)]NO3 (acac− =acetylacetonato ligand, tmen=N,N,N′,N′-tetramethyl-ethylendiamine) on styrene–divinylbenzene copolymer functionalized with four different dialkyl phosphonate moieties typified by PPO(OR)2 (with R= CH3, C2H5, i C3H7, and n C4H9). The formation of P(O)(OR)2 phosphonates groups has been confirmed by the FT-IR spectra. Thermogravimetric analysis results reveal that the thermal stability of polymer support depend on the functional group attached. The complexes were anchored by coordination interaction between the copper(II) ion and the phosphonate oxygen atom on each of the four functionalized supports and the strength of the PO⋯Cu n+ coordination interaction was influenced by the nature of the R group. The effect of functionalized supports on the structure and catalytic activity of Cu(hfac)2 and [Cu(acac)(tmen)]+ mononuclear species was determined in oxidation of several organic compounds (anisole, cyclohexene, toluene, styrene, phenol) with hydrogen peroxide. The catalytic activity results show that the activity and selectivity of Cu(II) complexes depends on the equilibrium between steric factor and inductive electron-releasing effect. The best selectivity was obtained in oxidation of anisole, phenol and styrene for all the catalysts. The main products were for 2-methoxyphenol, catechol and benzaldehyde, respectively.
coredata.dc:title: Supported monocationic copper(II) complexes obtained by coordination with dialkylphosphonate groups on styrene–divinylbenzene copolymer as catalysts for oxidation of organic compounds

coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
